Award.AwardTitle: INSPIRE Track 1: Mahali: Space Weather Monitoring Everywhere
Award.AbstractNarration:
This INSPIRE award is partially funded by the Geospace Facilities Program in the Division of Atmospheric and Geospace Sciences in the Directorate for Geoscience, and the Computing Research Infrastructure and Networking and Technology and Systems Programs in the Computer and Network Systems Division in the Directorate for Computer and Information Science and Engineering.

The investigators will perform a proof-of-concept demonstration of a revolutionary architecture that uses mobile devices to form a global space weather monitoring network. Current sensors observing the space weather environment are sparsely deployed and relatively costly to operate. A promising technique to overcome this issue leverages existing Global Positioning System (GPS) infrastructure; more specifically, delays in the multi-frequency GPS signals observed at the ground that are caused by ionospheric electron density. Modern mobile devices constitute a vast network of multicore parallel computers that provide the computational power needed for geospace data processing and storage. With connectivity available worldwide, even in remote places, mobile devices are thus excellent candidates to establish global relays that feed sensor data into a cloud processing environment that reconstructs the structure of the space environment, and its dynamic changes. This project will enable space weather data collection even in the most remote places on Earth, resulting in dramatic improvements in observational gaps that exist in space weather research today. Kila Mahali means "everywhere" in the Swahili language. Space weather phenomena in Earth's upper atmosphere influence our daily lives, but prior technical limitations have made a thorough understanding of these phenomena difficult. In today's networked society, it is critical to monitor and predict extreme space weather events and their impacts on the ionosphere, because they can affect human systems for power, communications, and navigation. Recent studies have also demonstrated that tsunamis and earthquakes perturb the density of electrons in the ionosphere, and that even climate change has a measurable impact on ionospheric electron density. This interdisciplinary project explores how to make this possible by leveraging mobile devices as enabling relays for a dense mesh of measurements. This approach will create totally new opportunities for Space Weather monitoring, scientific investigation, and potentially use of the entire ionosphere as a sensor to monitor natural disasters and help save human lives.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The Mahali project is interdisciplinary in nature and follows the spirit of “Kila Mahali” which means “everywhere” in Swahili language. The project made several contributions that not only showed solutions to particular problems but also provided more general ways to attack those problems in geosciences.  For example, it demonstrated the use of mobile phones as data relays for space weather applications, where space weather refers to dynamic changes in the Earth’s ionosphere and near-space environment. Observing the Earth’s ionosphere with a denser infrastructure for space weather monitoring has the advantage that phenomena can be observed and understood in much greater detail. This includes solar storms, which can impact our infrastructure such as satellites and the electric grid, and other earth-based hazards such as Earthquakes and Tsunami which produce detectable signatures in ionospheric data.  

The principles leveraged here rely on signals transmitted from regular GPS satellites, which pass through the Earth’s ionosphere, but which get distorted and/or delayed depending on ionospheric activity and the number of electrons within the line of sight from satellite to the user. Multi-frequency GPS receivers on the ground can pick up these signals and isolate the changes induced by the ionosphere. The project shows that this kind of signal analysis can be done on phones, and data transfer to a central computational facility can be handled there as well. It also provides a real world testbed for multi-core computing algorithms used on mobile devices, which have additional challenges related to parallel computing, power consumption, and data movement constraints that require an adaptive approach for different situations. The software framework created in this project for Android phones is reusable and extensible, and it has been released as open source code to the public on the popular Github repository.

This research has produced ideas which make it much easier and more affordable to transfer data on space weather from many locations, compared to traditional instrumentation that requires special hardware for collection and communication. As a feasibility demonstration, a field deployment with a small number of receivers occurred during the project in remote portions of Alaska (that lack traditional data transfer options) near the Poker Flat rocket range, at distances of up at 250 km between systems. The Poker Flat Incoherent Scatter Radar (PFISR), a large NSF ionospheric radar facility, was operated at the same time to collect additional precise ionospheric measurements for use in analysis and comparison of the Mahali GPS data. Results have shown details of space weather and space physics effects, including active auroral precipitation over instrument locations, during several scientifically interesting geomagnetic events. The direct impacts of the auroral precipitation on the ground based GPS receivers were also observed by this experiment. They were particularly novel and indicate impacts from lower in altitude than has previously been understood.

Finally, the fertile ground of this project has enabled a broad collaboration and joint publications spanning different academic institutions, as well as the exposure and/or participation of postdoctoral researchers, university students, and high school students.
